findings.claim: Achieved 500% revenue growth ($5,000k vs $1,000k) through sheer manual effort of the remaining team (15 employees) despite closing all manufacturing facilities
findings.contradiction: Operational impossibility: Generating 5x revenue growth in a hardware business while closing all production facilities and reducing workforce by 85% violates business logic.
findings.reasoning: Revenue increased from $1M to $5M, implying a 5x increase in product volume (assuming stable pricing). However, the company closed 'all three manufacturing facilities' and reduced headcount to 15 people. The MD&A attributes this to 'manual effort', but it is physically impossible for 15 people to manually produce 5x the output of a previously larger workforce supported by three factories. There is no mention of outsourcing to explain the production volume.
source_refs: Income Statement (Revenue)
MD&A Paragraph 1

findings.claim: Market share increased to 25%, while primary competitor (80% share) doubled their sales
findings.contradiction: The combined market share claims result in a total market exceeding 100%, which is mathematically impossible.
findings.reasoning: In FY 2024, Veritas had $1M revenue (10% share), implying a Total Market of $10M. The competitor (80% share) had $8M revenue. In FY 2025, the competitor doubled sales to $16M. Veritas had $5M revenue. If Veritas's $5M represents a 25% market share, the implied Total Market is $20M ($5M / 0.25). However, the competitor's $16M revenue alone would represent 80% of that $20M market. Veritas (25%) + Competitor (80%) = 105%, leaving no room for other players and exceeding 100%.
source_refs: MD&A Paragraph 2
Income Statement (Revenue)

findings.claim: Recorded $450k in depreciation expense for the full year ended December 31, 2025, for machinery decommissioned on January 1, 2025
findings.contradiction: Temporal contradiction: Depreciation was recorded for a period after the asset was removed from service.
findings.reasoning: The note states the facility was closed and machinery decommissioned/listed for sale on Jan 1, 2025. Standard accounting logic dictates that depreciation ceases when an asset is retired from active use and held for sale. Charging 'full year' depreciation for an asset not in use during that year is logically inconsistent with the stated timeline.
source_refs: Note 4: Property, Plant, and Equipment

findings.summary: Former employee filed wrongful termination lawsuit against Veritas Tech Inc. in Q4 2025
findings.potential_contradiction: No mention of legal proceedings in financial statements

verifications.claim: Opened new manufacturing facility in Austin, Texas in March 2025
verifications.evidence_summary: Public records show the facility address is a vacant lot. No business permits found.
verifications.discrepancy: Address does not correspond to any commercial building

findings.summary: Former employee filed wrongful termination lawsuit against Veritas Tech Inc. in Q4 2025
findings.details:
Publication date: 2025-11-15
Potential contradiction: No mention of legal proceedings in financial statements

findings.requirement: A statement of financial position at the period end date is required. The provided document only contains a Statement of Operations.
A statement of changes in equity for the period is required. No such statement was found in the provided text.
A statement of cash flows for the period is required. No such statement was found in the provided text.
An explicit and unreserved statement in the notes that the financial statements comply with IFRS is required. This statement is missing.
Notes disclosing the basis of preparation of the financial statements and specific accounting policies used are required. Only Note 4 (PPE) was provided; general policy notes are missing.
The statement of profit or loss must present a line item for tax expense. The provided Statement of Operations calculates Net Income directly from Operating Expenses without showing Tax Expense.

A single amount for the total of discontinued operations is required in the statement of profit or loss. Note 4 and MD&A indicate the closure of all manufacturing facilities and decommissioning of machinery, which likely constitutes a discontinued operation under IFRS 5, yet no separate line item is presented.
The financial statements are missing the accounting policy for inventories, specifically the cost formula used (for example, FIFO or weighted average cost).
The document lacks a disclosure of the carrying amount of inventories in total and sub-classified by main categories appropriate to the entity (e.g., merchandise, materials, finished goods).
There is no disclosure regarding performance obligations in contracts with customers found in the document.
Disclosures describing performance obligations, including when they are typically satisfied, payment terms, and the nature of goods/services promised, are missing.
No disclosure was found regarding trade and other receivables.
Present information separately for interests in subsidiaries, joint ventures, etc.
Presentation of Basic and Diluted EPS
Disclosure of Numerators for EPS
Disclosure of Denominators (Weighted Average Shares)

findings.claim: Achieved 500% revenue growth ($5,000k vs $1,000k) through sheer manual effort of the remaining team (15 employees) despite closing all manufacturing facilities
findings.contradiction: Operational impossibility: Generating 5x revenue growth in a hardware business while closing all production facilities and reducing workforce by 85% violates business logic.
findings.reasoning: Revenue increased from $1M to $5M, implying a 5x increase in product volume. The company closed 'all three manufacturing facilities' and reduced headcount to 15 people, attributing growth to 'manual effort'. It is physically impossible for 15 people to manually produce 5x the output of a previously larger workforce supported by three factories without undisclosed outsourcing, suggesting a material misstatement or fraud risk.
source_refs: Income Statement (Revenue)
MD&A Paragraph 1

findings.claim: Market share increased to 25%, while primary competitor (80% share) doubled their sales
findings.contradiction: The combined market share claims result in a total market exceeding 100%, which is mathematically impossible.
findings.reasoning: In FY 2025, Veritas claims 25% share with $5M revenue (implied Total Market $20M). The competitor, controlling 80% of the market, doubled sales to $16M (80% of $20M). Summing Veritas (25%) and the Competitor (80%) equals 105% of the market, which is logically impossible and undermines the reliability of the MD&A disclosure.
source_refs: MD&A Paragraph 2
Income Statement (Revenue)

findings.claim: Recorded $450k in depreciation expense for the full year ended December 31, 2025, for machinery decommissioned on January 1, 2025
findings.contradiction: Temporal contradiction: Depreciation was recorded for a period after the asset was removed from service.
findings.reasoning: The note states the facility was closed and machinery decommissioned/listed for sale on Jan 1, 2025. Standard accounting logic dictates that depreciation ceases when an asset is retired from active use and held for sale. Charging 'full year' depreciation for an asset not in use constitutes a compliance risk and potential material misstatement of expenses.
source_refs: Note 4: Property, Plant, and Equipment

findings.requirement: Presentation of Basic and Diluted EPS
findings.description: 66 An entity shall present in the statement of comprehensive income basic and diluted earnings per share for profit or loss from continuing operations attributable to the ordinary equity holders of the parent entity and for profit or loss attributable to the ordinary equity holders of the parent entity for the period for each class of ordinary shares that has a different right to share in profit for the period. An entity shall present basic and diluted earnings per share with equal prominence for all periods presented.

findings.requirement: Disclosure of Numerators for EPS
findings.description: (a) the amounts used as the numerators in calculating basic and diluted earnings per share, and a reconciliation of those amounts to profit or loss attributable to the parent entity for the period. The reconciliation should include the individual effect of each class of instruments that affects earnings per share;

findings.requirement: Disclosure of Denominators (Weighted Average Shares)
findings.description: (b) the weighted average number of ordinary shares used as the denominator in calculating basic and diluted earnings per share, and a reconciliation of these denominators to each other. The reconciliation should include the individual effect of each class of instruments that affects earnings per share; and

findings.requirement: Inventories, including the cost formula used
findings.description: The financial statements are missing the accounting policy for inventories, specifically the cost formula used (for example, FIFO or weighted average cost).

findings.requirement: Carrying amount of inventories and sub-classification
findings.description: The document lacks a disclosure of the carrying amount of inventories in total and sub-classified by main categories appropriate to the entity (e.g., merchandise, materials, finished goods).

findings.requirement: Contracts with Customers - Performance obligations
findings.description: There is no disclosure regarding performance obligations in contracts with customers found in the document.

findings.requirement: Information about performance obligations
findings.description: Disclosures describing performance obligations, including when they are typically satisfied, payment terms, and the nature of goods/services promised, are missing.

findings.requirement: Trade and other receivables
findings.description: No disclosure was found regarding trade and other receivables.

findings.requirement: Present information separately for interests in subsidiaries, joint ventures, etc.
findings.description: The financial statements are titled 'Consolidated Statements of Operations', which indicates the existence of subsidiaries. However, the provided document presents no information regarding the entity's interests in subsidiaries, failing the requirement to present information separately for interests in subsidiaries.

findings.requirement: Statement of financial position
findings.description: A statement of financial position at the period end date is required. The provided document only contains a Statement of Operations.

findings.requirement: Statement of changes in equity
findings.description: A statement of changes in equity for the period is required. No such statement was found in the provided text.

findings.requirement: Statement of cash flows
findings.description: A statement of cash flows for the period is required. No such statement was found in the provided text.

findings.requirement: Statement of compliance with IFRS
findings.description: An explicit and unreserved statement in the notes that the financial statements comply with IFRS is required. This statement is missing.

findings.requirement: Basis of preparation and accounting policies
findings.description: Notes disclosing the basis of preparation of the financial statements and specific accounting policies used are required. Only Note 4 (PPE) was provided; general policy notes are missing.

findings.requirement: Tax expense line item
findings.description: The statement of profit or loss must present a line item for tax expense. The provided Statement of Operations calculates Net Income directly from Operating Expenses without showing Tax Expense.

findings.requirement: Discontinued operations line item
findings.description: A single amount for the total of discontinued operations is required in the statement of profit or loss. Note 4 and MD&A indicate the closure of all manufacturing facilities and decommissioning of machinery, which likely constitutes a discontinued operation under IFRS 5, yet no separate line item is presented.

findings.requirement: Disclosure of employee benefits expense
findings.description: IAS 19 does not require specific disclosures about short-term employee benefits, but other IFRSs may require disclosures. For example, IAS 24 requires disclosures about employee benefits for key management personnel. IAS 1 requires disclosure of employee benefits expense. (see also A5.19.7)
